name: Human Body - Skeletal and Muscular Systems

in_scope: Functions of skeleton: support, protection, movement, blood cell production
Major bones: skull, ribs, spine (backbone), limb bones
Skull protects brain, rib cage protects heart and lungs
Spine made of vertebrae, allows bending
Types of joints: hinge (knee, elbow), ball-and-socket (shoulder, hip), pivot (neck)
Fixed joints: skull bones
Muscles attached to bones by tendons
Muscles work in pairs (one contracts, one relaxes)
Caring for bones: calcium-rich foods (milk, cheese)
Caring for muscles: exercise, proper posture
out_of_scope: Basic body parts only - Covered in Class 1-2
Detailed bone anatomy and names - Introduced in Class 6-7
Muscle tissue types - Introduced in Class 7
Skeletal disorders in detail - Introduced in Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Parts of a flower and their functions

in_scope: Flower parts: sepals, petals, stamens (male), pistil (female)
Stamen: anther (pollen) and filament
Pistil: stigma, style, ovary
Pollination: transfer of pollen from anther to stigma
Self-pollination and cross-pollination
Agents of pollination: wind, water, insects, birds
Seed formation after pollination
Parts of seed: seed coat, cotyledon, embryo
Seed dispersal by: wind, water, animals, explosion
Conditions for germination: water, air, warmth
Stages of germination
out_of_scope: Basic plant parts only - Covered in Class 1-2
Fertilization process - Introduced in Class 7
Double fertilization - Introduced in Class 8
Vegetative propagation in detail - Introduced in Class 7

in_scope: Habitat classification: land, water, air, amphibians
Body coverings: fur, feathers, scales, shell, moist skin
Food habits: herbivores, carnivores, omnivores
Vertebrates vs invertebrates (basic introduction)
Butterfly life cycle: egg - caterpillar (larva) - pupa - adult
Mosquito life cycle: egg - larva - pupa - adult
Frog life cycle: egg - tadpole - froglet - adult frog
Metamorphosis: complete change in body form during growth
Examples of metamorphosis in insects and frogs
out_of_scope: Basic animal types only - Covered in Class 1-2
Detailed vertebrate classification - Introduced in Class 6-7
Reproduction in animals - Introduced in Class 8
Insect anatomy in detail - Introduced in Class 7

concepts.concept_name: Types of nutrients and their sources

in_scope: Nutrients: carbohydrates (energy), proteins (growth), fats (energy storage)
Vitamins and minerals (general importance)
Sources of nutrients in common foods
Balanced diet: eating different food groups
Digestive organs: mouth, food pipe (esophagus), stomach, small intestine, large intestine
Digestion starts in mouth with saliva
Stomach churns and mixes food
Small intestine absorbs nutrients
Large intestine absorbs water, removes waste
Types of teeth: incisors (cutting), canines (tearing), molars (grinding)
Milk teeth and permanent teeth
out_of_scope: Basic food types only - Covered in Class 1-2
Enzymes and chemical digestion - Introduced in Class 7
Detailed nutrient chemistry - Introduced in Class 8
Deficiency diseases - Introduced in Class 6

concepts.concept_name: Properties of solids, liquids, and gases

in_scope: Three states of matter: solid, liquid, gas
Solids: definite shape and volume
Liquids: no definite shape, definite volume
Gases: no definite shape or volume
Melting: solid to liquid
Freezing: liquid to solid
Evaporation/boiling: liquid to gas
Condensation: gas to liquid
Water cycle as example of state changes
Reversible changes: can go back (ice melting)
Irreversible changes: cannot go back (cooking, burning)
Materials: natural (wood, cotton) and man-made (plastic, glass)
out_of_scope: Living vs non-living only - Covered in Class 2
Particle theory of matter - Introduced in Class 6
Physical and chemical changes in detail - Introduced in Class 7
Plasma state - Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Force: a push or pull
Types: muscular force, gravitational force (gravity), frictional force, magnetic force
Effects of force: start motion, stop motion, change speed, change direction, change shape
Gravity pulls objects toward Earth
Friction slows down moving objects
Types of energy: heat, light, sound, electrical, mechanical
Energy makes things work/move
Energy can change from one form to another
Sources of energy: Sun, food, fuels, electricity, batteries
Renewable: sun, wind, water
Non-renewable: coal, oil, gas
out_of_scope: Basic push and pull only - Covered in Class 1-2
Force measurement and units - Introduced in Class 6
Work and energy calculations - Introduced in Class 8
Conservation of energy - Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Natural sources: Sun, stars, fire, lightning
Artificial sources: bulb, torch, candle, tube light
Light travels in straight lines
Light travels very fast
Transparent objects: light passes through completely (glass, water, air)
Translucent objects: some light passes through (frosted glass, oiled paper)
Opaque objects: no light passes through (wood, metal, stone)
Shadow forms when light is blocked by opaque object
Shadow size changes with position of light source
Reflection: light bouncing off surfaces
Smooth surfaces reflect better (mirrors)
out_of_scope: Day and night only - Covered in Class 1-2
Laws of reflection - Introduced in Class 7
Refraction of light - Introduced in Class 7
Speed of light - Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Sound is produced by vibrations
Vibrating objects make sound (drum, guitar string, vocal cords)
Sound needs a medium to travel (air, water, solid)
Sound cannot travel in vacuum
Sound travels slower than light
Musical instruments: drums (vibrating membrane), guitar (vibrating strings)
Flute (vibrating air column), cymbals (vibrating metal)
Loudness: loud sounds from more energy, soft sounds from less energy
Pitch: high sounds (whistle) and low sounds (drum)
Pleasant sounds: music, birdsong
Unpleasant sounds (noise): traffic, loud machines
Noise pollution and its effects
out_of_scope: Basic sounds identification only - Covered in Class 1-2
Sound waves and frequency - Introduced in Class 8
Echo and reflection of sound - Introduced in Class 8
Decibel measurements - Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Sun is a star, source of light and heat for Earth
Sun is the center of our solar system
Earth rotates on its axis: causes day and night (24 hours)
Earth revolves around Sun: causes seasons (1 year = 365 days)
Moon is Earth's natural satellite
Moon revolves around Earth (about 28 days)
Moon phases: new moon, crescent, half moon, full moon
Moon reflects sunlight
8 planets: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune
Order of planets from Sun
Earth is the only planet with life (that we know of)
Stars are far away suns
Constellations: groups of stars forming patterns
out_of_scope: Day and night basic concept only - Covered in Class 1-2
Eclipses - Introduced in Class 6
Detailed study of planets - Introduced in Class 6-7
Space exploration - Introduced in Class 7

in_scope: Natural disasters: harmful events caused by nature
Cannot be prevented but we can prepare
Earthquakes: sudden shaking of Earth's surface
Earthquake safety: hide under table, stay away from buildings
Floods: too much water covering land
Causes of floods: heavy rain, overflowing rivers
Droughts: no rain for long time, water shortage
Cyclones: strong winds with heavy rain
Thunderstorms: lightning and thunder
Stay indoors during storms
Emergency kit: water, food, flashlight, first aid
Importance of following warnings and instructions
out_of_scope: Basic weather only - Covered in Class 1-2
Tectonic plates - Introduced in Class 7
Disaster management in detail - Introduced in Class 8
Climate change causes - Introduced in Class 7

concepts.concept_name: The three Rs: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle

in_scope: Air pollution: smoke from vehicles, factories, burning
Water pollution: chemicals, garbage, sewage in water
Land pollution: plastic, garbage on land
Noise pollution: loud sounds from traffic, machines
Effects: health problems, harm to animals and plants
Conservation: protecting and saving natural resources
Saving water, electricity, fuel
Reduce: use less (less plastic, less paper)
Reuse: use again (old clothes, bottles)
Recycle: make new from old (paper recycling)
Plant trees, use public transport
Say no to plastic bags
out_of_scope: Basic clean/dirty only - Covered in Class 1-2
Greenhouse effect - Introduced in Class 7
Global warming in detail - Introduced in Class 8
Environmental laws - Introduced in Class 9

in_scope: Simple machines: devices that make work easier
Six simple machines: lever, pulley, wheel and axle, inclined plane, wedge, screw
Lever: rod that rotates around a fixed point (fulcrum)
Examples of levers: see-saw, scissors, bottle opener, pliers
Inclined plane: sloped surface
Examples: ramps, slides, sloping roads
Wedge: two inclined planes together
Examples: knife, axe, nail
Pulley: wheel with a rope
Examples: flagpole, well, cranes
Wheel and axle: wheel attached to rod
Examples: door knob, steering wheel, screwdriver
Screw: inclined plane wrapped around cylinder
Examples: screws, jar lids, light bulbs
out_of_scope: Basic tools only - Covered in Class 1-2
Mechanical advantage calculations - Introduced in Class 8
Complex machines - Introduced in Class 7
Classes of levers - Introduced in Class 7
